canonical_explanation.text: Heredity is the transmission of traits from parents to offspring through genes. Gregor Mendel, the father of genetics, studied inheritance patterns using pea plants and established fundamental laws. In a monohybrid cross (Tt x Tt), the phenotypic ratio is 3:1 (dominant:recessive). In a dihybrid cross, the phenotypic ratio is 9:3:3:1. Traits are controlled by genes present on chromosomes. Sex in humans is determined by sex chromosomes: females have XX and males have XY. Evolution is the gradual change in inherited characteristics of a population over generations. Evidence includes homologous organs, analogous organs, and fossils. Natural selection, as proposed by Darwin, drives evolution by favouring organisms with advantageous traits. Speciation occurs through geographical isolation and genetic drift. Evolution is not progress from lower to higher forms but adaptation to environments.
rules: Mendel's Law of Dominance: In a cross, only the dominant trait is expressed in F1 generation.
Mendel's Law of Segregation: Alleles separate during gamete formation; each gamete gets one allele.
Monohybrid cross F2 ratio: 3 dominant : 1 recessive (phenotypic); 1:2:1 (genotypic).
Sex determination: XX = female, XY = male; father's sperm determines sex of child.
Homologous organs: same origin, different function (evidence of common ancestry).
Analogous organs: different origin, similar function (evidence of convergent evolution).
Fossils provide evidence of organisms that lived in the past and their evolutionary relationships.

questions.question_text: Who is known as the 'Father of Genetics'?
questions.explanation_correct: Gregor Johann Mendel (1822-1884) is known as the 'Father of Genetics'. He was an Austrian monk who conducted extensive experiments on pea plants (Pisum sativum) and discovered the fundamental laws of inheritance that form the basis of modern genetics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Charles Darwin proposed the theory of evolution by natural selection. Louis Pasteur made contributions to microbiology. Robert Hooke discovered cells. Mendel is specifically recognized as the Father of Genetics for his work on inheritance.

questions.question_text: In Mendel's experiments, the trait that appears in the F1 generation is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The dominant trait is the one that is expressed (appears) in the F1 generation when two pure (homozygous) parents with contrasting traits are crossed. For example, when tall (TT) and short (tt) pea plants are crossed, all F1 plants are tall because tallness is dominant over shortness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The recessive trait is hidden in F1 and only appears in F2 generation. Acquired traits are not inherited. Co-dominance is when both alleles are equally expressed (not seen in Mendel's experiments). The trait appearing in F1 is the dominant trait.

questions.question_text: The phenotypic ratio of a monohybrid cross in the F2 generation is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a monohybrid cross (e.g., Tt x Tt), the F2 generation shows a phenotypic ratio of 3:1 — three organisms showing the dominant trait for every one showing the recessive trait. The genotypic ratio is 1:2:1 (TT:Tt:tt).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1:1 is the ratio of a test cross. 9:3:3:1 is the phenotypic ratio of a dihybrid cross. 1:2:1 is the genotypic ratio of a monohybrid cross. The phenotypic ratio of a monohybrid F2 generation is 3:1.

questions.question_text: The physical appearance of an organism for a particular trait is called its:
questions.explanation_correct: Phenotype refers to the observable physical characteristics or appearance of an organism for a particular trait (e.g., tall or short, round or wrinkled seeds). It is determined by the genotype (genetic makeup) and can be influenced by environmental factors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Genotype is the genetic makeup (e.g., TT, Tt, tt). An allele is an alternative form of a gene. A chromosome is a structure carrying genes. Phenotype specifically refers to the observable physical characteristics.

questions.question_text: In humans, sex is determined by:
questions.explanation_correct: Sex in humans is determined by sex chromosomes. Females have two X chromosomes (XX) and males have one X and one Y chromosome (XY). The father's sperm determines the sex of the child — a sperm carrying X produces a girl and a sperm carrying Y produces a boy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Autosomes are non-sex chromosomes (22 pairs in humans). Nutrition does not determine sex. Blood group is not related to sex determination. Sex chromosomes (X and Y) specifically determine the biological sex.

questions.question_text: A human female has the sex chromosome combination:
questions.explanation_correct: Human females have two X chromosomes (XX). They can only produce eggs containing the X chromosome. Males have one X and one Y chromosome (XY) and can produce sperm with either X or Y. This is why the father's sperm determines the sex of the child.
questions.explanation_incorrect: XY is the male combination. YY is not possible in humans. XO is a chromosomal abnormality (Turner syndrome). Females specifically have the XX sex chromosome combination.

questions.question_text: Organs that have the same basic structure and origin but different functions are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Homologous organs have the same basic structural plan and embryonic origin but perform different functions. For example, the forelimbs of humans (grasping), whales (swimming), bats (flying), and horses (running) all have the same bone structure but different functions. This indicates common ancestry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Analogous organs have different origins but similar functions. Vestigial organs are non-functional remnants of once-functional organs. Homologous organs specifically have the same origin and structure but different functions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following provides direct evidence of evolution?
questions.explanation_correct: Fossils are the preserved remains or impressions of organisms that lived in the past. They provide direct evidence of evolution by showing the existence of organisms that are now extinct and by revealing the gradual changes in body structures over millions of years in different rock layers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Homologous and analogous organs provide indirect evidence of evolution by showing structural similarities. Artificial selection shows how humans can change organisms. Fossils provide the most direct evidence by showing actual remains of past organisms.

questions.question_text: The process by which new species develop from existing species is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Speciation is the process of formation of new species from existing species. It occurs when populations become reproductively isolated (due to geographical barriers, genetic drift, or natural selection) and accumulate enough genetic differences that they can no longer interbreed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Natural selection is a mechanism of evolution but not the process of species formation itself. Genetic drift is random change in gene frequency. Mutation is a change in DNA. Speciation specifically refers to the formation of new species.

questions.question_text: Which plant did Mendel use for his experiments on inheritance?
questions.explanation_correct: Mendel used the garden pea plant (Pisum sativum) for his experiments. He chose peas because they have many contrasting traits (tall/short, round/wrinkled seeds, etc.), short generation time, produce many offspring, and can self-pollinate or be cross-pollinated easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mendel did not use rose, sunflower, or maize for his classic experiments. He specifically chose garden pea plants because of their distinct, easily observable contrasting characteristics and ease of controlled breeding.

questions.question_text: Wings of an insect and wings of a bird are examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: Wings of an insect and wings of a bird are analogous organs. They perform the same function (flying) but have completely different structural origins — insect wings are membranous extensions of the exoskeleton, while bird wings are modified forelimbs with bones and feathers. They evolved independently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Homologous organs share the same origin. Vestigial organs are non-functional remnants. They are not identical. Insect wings and bird wings are analogous because they serve the same function (flight) but have different structural origins — an example of convergent evolution.

questions.question_text: According to Mendel's law of segregation, alleles separate during gamete formation.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Mendel's Law of Segregation states that during the formation of gametes (eggs and sperm), the two alleles for each trait separate (segregate) so that each gamete receives only one allele. For example, a plant with genotype Tt produces gametes with either T or t, not both.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The law of segregation is one of Mendel's fundamental laws. During meiosis, paired alleles separate, ensuring each gamete carries only one allele for each gene.

questions.question_text: The mother determines the sex of the child in humans.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The father determines the sex of the child. The mother can only provide an X chromosome (since females are XX), while the father can provide either an X or a Y chromosome (since males are XY). If the sperm carries X, the child is female (XX); if the sperm carries Y, the child is male (XY).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mother always contributes an X chromosome. It is the father's sperm that determines the sex — X-bearing sperm produces a daughter (XX), Y-bearing sperm produces a son (XY). Therefore, the father determines the sex of the child.

questions.question_text: Acquired traits can be passed on to the next generation.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Acquired traits are changes that occur in an individual during its lifetime due to environmental factors (e.g., muscular body from exercise, knowledge from education). They do not cause changes in the DNA of reproductive cells and therefore cannot be inherited by the next generation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acquired traits are not heritable because they do not alter the DNA in the germ cells (reproductive cells). Only traits encoded in the DNA of gametes can be passed to offspring. For example, if a person builds muscles through exercise, their children will not be born with muscular bodies.

questions.question_text: Alternative forms of a gene that occupy the same position on homologous chromosomes are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Alleles are different forms of the same gene that code for alternative versions of a trait. For example, the gene for plant height has two alleles: T (tall) and t (short). An organism inherits one allele from each parent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'alleles'. They are variants of the same gene located at the same locus on homologous chromosomes. For any given trait, an organism has two alleles — one from each parent.

questions.question_text: The formation of new species due to geographical isolation over time is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Speciation is the process by which new species arise from existing ones. Geographic isolation separates populations, preventing gene flow between them. Over time, the isolated populations accumulate genetic differences through natural selection, genetic drift, and mutations, eventually becoming reproductively isolated and forming new species.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'speciation'. When a geographical barrier (mountain, river, ocean) divides a population, the separated groups evolve independently and may eventually become different species that cannot interbreed.

questions.question_text: The preserved remains or impressions of organisms that lived in the past are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Fossils are the preserved remains, traces, or impressions of organisms from the geological past found in rocks or sedimentary layers. They provide direct evidence of evolution by showing how organisms have changed over millions of years. Fossil dating can be done by studying rock layers or using radioactive dating methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fossils'. They are found in sedimentary rocks and include petrified bones, shells, leaf impressions, and footprints. The study of fossils is called palaeontology.

questions.question_text: The genetic makeup of an organism is called its ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Genotype refers to the genetic constitution of an organism — the specific combination of alleles for a trait. For example, TT (homozygous dominant), Tt (heterozygous), and tt (homozygous recessive) are different genotypes. The genotype determines the phenotype (physical appearance).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'genotype'. It represents the actual genetic composition using letters (e.g., TT, Tt, tt). The observable physical trait resulting from the genotype is called the phenotype.

questions.question_text: Evolution means progress from lower organisms to higher organisms.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Evolution is not about progress from 'lower' to 'higher' organisms. Evolution simply means changes in gene frequencies in a population over time, leading to adaptation to specific environments. All living organisms today are equally evolved. Simpler organisms are not 'less evolved' — they are well-adapted to their environments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evolution should not be equated with progress. It is about adaptation to environments, not a hierarchical ladder. Bacteria are just as 'evolved' as humans — they are simply adapted to different environments. There is no concept of 'higher' or 'lower' in evolution.

questions.question_text: The phenotypic ratio of a dihybrid cross in the F2 generation is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a dihybrid cross (involving two traits, e.g., RrYy x RrYy), the F2 generation shows a phenotypic ratio of 9:3:3:1. This means 9 show both dominant traits, 3 show first dominant and second recessive, 3 show first recessive and second dominant, and 1 shows both recessive traits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3:1 is the monohybrid ratio. 1:2:1 is the monohybrid genotypic ratio. 1:1:1:1 is a test cross ratio. The dihybrid cross F2 phenotypic ratio is specifically 9:3:3:1, demonstrating independent assortment.

questions.question_text: In a cross between a tall pea plant (Tt) and a short pea plant (tt), what percentage of offspring would be short?
questions.explanation_correct: In the cross Tt x tt, the offspring genotypes are: Tt, Tt, tt, tt (ratio 1:1). Two out of four (50%) are Tt (tall) and two out of four (50%) are tt (short). Therefore, 50% of the offspring would be short. This is a test cross pattern.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Working out the Punnett square: Tt x tt gives Tt, Tt, tt, tt. Half the offspring (50%) are short (tt) and half are tall (Tt). Not 25%, 75%, or 100%.

questions.question_text: If both parents have the genotype Tt (heterozygous tall), what fraction of the F2 offspring would be homozygous?
questions.explanation_correct: From the cross Tt x Tt, the offspring genotypes are TT, Tt, Tt, tt (ratio 1:2:1). Homozygous offspring are TT (1/4) and tt (1/4), totalling 2/4 = 1/2. So half the offspring are homozygous (either TT or tt) and the other half are heterozygous (Tt).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Punnett square gives TT:Tt:Tt:tt. Homozygous means having identical alleles — TT and tt are both homozygous. So 1/4 (TT) + 1/4 (tt) = 1/2 of the offspring are homozygous.

questions.question_text: A couple has four daughters. What is the probability that their next child will be a son?

options.text: 100%, since they already have four daughters
0%, since the mother can only produce daughters

questions.explanation_correct: The probability of having a son is always 50% for each pregnancy, regardless of how many daughters (or sons) the couple already has. Each conception is an independent event. The father has an equal chance of contributing an X or Y sperm, so the probability of a boy (XY) is always 1/2 (50%).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Previous children do not influence the sex of the next child. Each pregnancy is an independent event with a 50-50 chance. The mother always contributes X, and the father has an equal probability of contributing X or Y. So the chance is always 50%.

questions.question_text: The forelimb of a human and the wing of a bat have similar bone structure but different functions. What does this indicate?

options.text: They evolved from completely different ancestors
They share a common ancestor and have diverged over time
They developed the same function independently
There is no evolutionary relationship between them

questions.explanation_correct: Similar bone structure (humerus, radius, ulna, carpals, metacarpals, phalanges) in the forelimbs of humans and bat wings indicates they share a common ancestor. Over time, these structures diverged to perform different functions (grasping vs flying) — this is divergent evolution shown by homologous organs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same basic structure indicates common ancestry, not independent evolution. There is a clear evolutionary relationship shown by shared skeletal structure. This is an example of homologous organs indicating divergent evolution from a common ancestor.

questions.question_text: On an island, a population of beetles has both green and brown variants. If crows preferentially eat green beetles, after many generations the population will likely:

options.text: Have no change in beetle colour distribution
Have all beetles turn into a new colour

questions.explanation_correct: This is natural selection in action. If crows preferentially eat green beetles, green beetles are less likely to survive and reproduce. Brown beetles have a survival advantage (better camouflage), so over many generations, the proportion of brown beetles in the population will increase. This is an example of natural selection favouring advantageous traits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Green beetles would decrease (not increase) because they are being selectively eaten. The population would change (not remain the same). Beetles do not spontaneously change colour. Natural selection would increase the frequency of brown beetles over generations.

questions.question_text: In a monohybrid cross between two heterozygous parents (Tt x Tt), what percentage of offspring would show the recessive phenotype?
questions.explanation_correct: From Tt x Tt, the offspring are TT (1), Tt (2), tt (1) — genotypic ratio 1:2:1. Only tt shows the recessive phenotype. Since 1 out of 4 offspring is tt, 25% of the offspring would show the recessive trait. The remaining 75% (TT and Tt) would show the dominant trait.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Punnett square for Tt x Tt gives: 1 TT + 2 Tt + 1 tt. Only tt (1 out of 4) shows the recessive phenotype. That is 25%, not 0%, 50%, or 75%.

questions.question_text: A scientist discovers a fossil of a fish with limb-like fins. What does this suggest?

options.text: Fish and land animals are not related
This organism is a possible transitional form between fish and early land animals

questions.explanation_correct: A fossil of a fish with limb-like fins suggests it is a transitional form (connecting link) between aquatic fish and early land-dwelling animals. Such fossils show intermediate characteristics and provide evidence for the evolution of land vertebrates from fish ancestors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Such fossils show a clear evolutionary relationship between fish and land animals. Land animals evolved from fish ancestors, not the other way around. Fossils with intermediate features are valuable evidence of evolutionary transitions.

questions.question_text: How does geographical isolation lead to speciation?

options.text: It causes organisms to become stronger
It prevents gene flow between separated populations, allowing them to evolve differently
It increases the food supply for both populations
It has no effect on species formation

questions.explanation_correct: Geographical isolation (by mountains, rivers, etc.) separates a population into two groups that can no longer interbreed. Each group faces different environmental conditions and accumulates different mutations and adaptations through natural selection and genetic drift. Over many generations, the groups become so genetically different that they can no longer interbreed — forming new species.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Geographical isolation does not make organisms stronger or affect food supply. It does affect species formation. The key mechanism is prevention of gene flow, allowing independent evolution in separate populations.

questions.question_text: A man with blood type A (heterozygous, IAi) marries a woman with blood type B (heterozygous, IBi). What blood types can their children have?
questions.explanation_correct: From IAi x IBi: the possible offspring genotypes are IAIB (AB), IAi (A), IBi (B), and ii (O). Therefore, all four blood types are possible. This cross demonstrates co-dominance (IA and IB are co-dominant to each other) and dominance (both are dominant over i).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Punnett square for IAi x IBi gives all four possible blood types: IAIB (type AB), IAi (type A), IBi (type B), and ii (type O). All blood types are possible, not just some.

questions.question_text: Why are fossils found in deeper layers of earth generally older than those in upper layers?

options.text: Because older organisms were heavier and sank deeper
Because sedimentary layers are deposited chronologically — older at the bottom, newer on top
Because organisms preferred living underground in earlier times

questions.explanation_correct: Sedimentary rocks form in layers (strata) over time. Older layers are deposited first and are found at the bottom, while newer layers are deposited on top. Since fossils form within these layers, fossils in deeper layers are older than those in upper layers. This principle is called the 'law of superposition'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weight does not determine fossil depth. Newer fossils do not dissolve faster. Organisms did not live underground. The correct explanation is the chronological deposition of sedimentary layers — older layers (and their fossils) are at the bottom.

questions.question_text: In a monohybrid cross, the F1 generation shows only the dominant trait when both parents are homozygous for contrasting traits.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. When homozygous dominant (TT) is crossed with homozygous recessive (tt), all F1 offspring are heterozygous (Tt). Since T is dominant over t, all F1 plants express only the dominant trait (tall). The recessive trait reappears in the F2 generation in a 3:1 ratio.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. In TT x tt cross, all F1 offspring are Tt. The dominant allele T masks the recessive allele t, so only the dominant phenotype is expressed in the entire F1 generation.

questions.question_text: In humans, the sex of the child is determined by the ___ parent, who contributes either an X or Y chromosome.
questions.explanation_correct: The father (male parent) determines the sex of the child because he produces two types of sperm — one carrying the X chromosome and one carrying the Y chromosome. The mother always contributes an X chromosome. If X-sperm fertilizes the egg, the child is XX (girl); if Y-sperm fertilizes the egg, the child is XY (boy).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'father'. Since the mother can only contribute X chromosomes (being XX herself), it is the father's sperm (carrying either X or Y) that determines whether the child will be male or female.

questions.question_text: The process by which organisms with favourable traits are more likely to survive and reproduce is called natural ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Natural selection is the process proposed by Charles Darwin where organisms with traits better suited to their environment are more likely to survive, reproduce, and pass those traits to the next generation. Over time, this leads to the accumulation of advantageous traits in the population.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'selection'. Natural selection is the driving mechanism of evolution. Organisms better adapted to their environment have a higher fitness (survival and reproductive success), leading to changes in the population's traits over generations.

questions.question_text: Random changes in gene frequency in a small population, not caused by natural selection, are called genetic ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Genetic drift refers to random fluctuations in allele (gene) frequencies in a population, especially significant in small populations. Unlike natural selection, genetic drift is not directed by the environment. It can lead to the fixation or loss of alleles by chance, contributing to speciation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'drift'. Genetic drift is a random, non-directional evolutionary mechanism. In small populations, chance events can significantly alter gene frequencies, sometimes leading to the loss of genetic diversity or fixation of certain alleles.

questions.question_text: Why did Mendel choose pea plants for his experiments?

options.text: Because pea plants are the largest plants
Because they have clearly contrasting traits, short generation time, and can be easily cross-pollinated
Because they are the only plants that show heredity
Because they produce only one offspring per generation

questions.explanation_correct: Mendel chose pea plants because they had several advantages: clearly distinguishable contrasting traits (7 pairs), short generation time (one growing season), could be self-pollinated or cross-pollinated easily, produced many offspring per cross, and were easy to grow and maintain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pea plants are not the largest plants. All organisms show heredity, not just peas. Peas produce many seeds per cross, not just one. The key reasons were clear contrasting traits, easy manipulation, and short generation time.

questions.question_text: In a cross between round yellow (RrYy) and wrinkled green (rryy) pea plants, the phenotypic ratio of the offspring would be:
questions.explanation_correct: In the cross RrYy x rryy (a dihybrid test cross), the possible offspring are: RrYy (round yellow), Rryy (round green), rrYy (wrinkled yellow), rryy (wrinkled green), each with a probability of 1/4. The phenotypic ratio is 1:1:1:1. This is different from the F2 dihybrid ratio (9:3:3:1) because one parent is homozygous recessive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 9:3:3:1 occurs only when both parents are dihybrid heterozygous (RrYy x RrYy). 3:1 is a monohybrid ratio. 1:1 is a monohybrid test cross ratio. This dihybrid test cross (RrYy x rryy) gives a 1:1:1:1 ratio.

questions.question_text: Explain how the sex of a child is determined in humans. What is the probability of a boy being born?

options.text: Father's sperm determines sex; 50% probability of boy (XY from Y-bearing sperm)
Both parents equally decide; 25% probability of boy
It is random; probability cannot be determined

questions.explanation_correct: Sex determination in humans depends on which type of sperm fertilizes the egg. The father produces two types of sperm: X-bearing (50%) and Y-bearing (50%). The mother always contributes an X chromosome. If Y-sperm fertilizes the egg → XY (boy). If X-sperm fertilizes the egg → XX (girl). So the probability of a boy is 50%.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mother only contributes X chromosomes and cannot determine sex. Both parents do not equally decide — only the father's sperm type matters. The probability is known (50%) and is not random in the sense of being unpredictable.

questions.question_text: Differentiate between homologous and analogous organs with examples.

options.text: Homologous: same function, different origin; Analogous: different function, same origin
Homologous: same origin, different function (e.g., human arm and whale flipper); Analogous: different origin, same function (e.g., bird wing and insect wing)
Both are exactly the same concept
Homologous organs are found only in plants; analogous organs only in animals

questions.explanation_correct: Homologous organs have the same embryonic origin and basic structure but perform different functions (e.g., human arm, whale flipper, bat wing — all have similar bone structure). They indicate divergent evolution from a common ancestor. Analogous organs have different origins but similar functions (e.g., bird wing and insect wing — both for flight but different structures). They indicate convergent evolution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the definitions. They are not the same concept. Both types are found in animals and sometimes plants. The correct differentiation is: homologous = same origin, different function; analogous = different origin, same function.

questions.question_text: How does genetic drift differ from natural selection as a mechanism of evolution?

options.text: There is no difference between them
Genetic drift is random change in gene frequency in small populations; natural selection is directed change based on environmental fitness
Genetic drift occurs only in large populations
Natural selection is random while genetic drift is directed

questions.explanation_correct: Genetic drift is the random change in allele frequencies in a population, especially pronounced in small populations. It occurs by chance, not based on fitness. Natural selection is a directed process where organisms with traits suited to the environment have better survival and reproduction rates. Both cause evolution but through different mechanisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are different mechanisms. Genetic drift is most significant in small populations (not large). Natural selection is directed (not random). The key difference is that genetic drift is random while natural selection is based on environmental fitness.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: When Mendel crossed tall and short pea plants, all F1 plants were tall.
Reason: Tallness is the dominant trait over shortness in pea plants.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both are true, but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. When TT (tall) is crossed with tt (short), all F1 offspring are Tt. Since tallness (T) is dominant over shortness (t), the T allele masks the t allele, and all F1 plants appear tall. This demonstrates Mendel's Law of Dominance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — Mendel observed all tall plants in F1. The reason is also true — tallness is dominant. And the reason explains why all F1 plants were tall: the dominant allele masks the recessive allele in heterozygous (Tt) organisms.

questions.question_text: What is the importance of studying the evolution of human beings from available evidence?

options.text: It helps us understand our origin, migration patterns, and relationships with other species
It is only useful for making movies
It only tells us about the future of humans

questions.explanation_correct: Studying human evolution helps us understand where we came from, how modern humans (Homo sapiens) evolved in Africa and migrated across the world, our relationships with other primates, how our brain and tools evolved over time, and why different human populations have certain physical characteristics adapted to their environments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The study of human evolution has immense scientific importance. It does not predict the future but explains the past. It helps us understand our biology, origins, diversity, and relationship to other species.

questions.question_text: Mendel's Law of Independent Assortment states that:

options.text: Alleles of one gene always stay with alleles of another gene
Alleles of different genes assort independently during gamete formation
All traits are always inherited together

questions.explanation_correct: Mendel's Law of Independent Assortment states that alleles of different genes are distributed independently during gamete formation. This means the inheritance of one trait (e.g., seed shape) does not affect the inheritance of another trait (e.g., seed colour). This is demonstrated by the 9:3:3:1 ratio in a dihybrid cross.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alleles of different genes do not stay together or always move as a group. Traits are not always inherited together (unless genes are linked on the same chromosome). The law specifically states that alleles of different genes assort independently.

questions.question_text: How have the evolution of eyes progressed in different organisms, according to the concept of 'evolution by stages'?

options.text: All organisms developed fully formed eyes at the same time
Eyes evolved gradually from simple light-sensitive spots to complex camera eyes, with each stage providing some survival advantage
Eyes cannot evolve because they are too complex

questions.explanation_correct: Eyes evolved in stages: from simple light-sensitive spots (in some flatworms) to cup-shaped eyes (providing directional information) to pinhole camera eyes (in nautilus) to lens eyes (in octopus and vertebrates). Each intermediate stage provided a survival advantage, making evolution of the next stage possible through natural selection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eyes did not appear fully formed at once. Many organisms have eyes, not just humans. Complex organs can evolve through gradual stages. Each stage of eye evolution provided a survival benefit — even a simple light-sensing patch is better than no light detection at all.

questions.question_text: In a family, the father is colour-blind (XᶜY) and the mother is a carrier (XXᶜ). What is the probability of their son being colour-blind?
questions.explanation_correct: The cross is XXᶜ x XᶜY. The sons can receive either X (normal) or Xᶜ (colour-blind) from the mother, and always receive Y from the father. So sons are either XY (normal vision) or XᶜY (colour-blind), each with 50% probability. Therefore, 50% of sons would be colour-blind.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sons receive their X chromosome from the mother (who is XXᶜ). Half the sons will get X (normal) and half will get Xᶜ (colour-blind). Since the Y from the father does not carry the gene for colour vision, 50% of sons will be colour-blind.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly represents an inherited trait and an acquired trait?

options.text: Inherited: ability to ride a bicycle; Acquired: eye colour
Inherited: eye colour; Acquired: ability to ride a bicycle
Both eye colour and cycling ability are inherited
Both eye colour and cycling ability are acquired

questions.explanation_correct: Eye colour is an inherited trait — it is determined by genes passed from parents and is present from birth. The ability to ride a bicycle is an acquired trait — it is learned through practice during one's lifetime and does not change the DNA. Inherited traits can be passed to offspring; acquired traits cannot.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cycling ability is learned (acquired), not inherited. Eye colour is genetic (inherited), not acquired. One is genetic, the other is environmental. The correct pairing is: inherited = eye colour, acquired = cycling ability.

questions.question_text: All modern humans (Homo sapiens) originated in Africa and then migrated to other continents.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true according to the 'Out of Africa' theory, which is supported by extensive fossil and genetic evidence. Modern Homo sapiens evolved in Africa approximately 200,000-300,000 years ago and then migrated to other continents in waves, eventually populating the entire globe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true based on current scientific evidence. Fossil records, genetic studies (DNA analysis), and archaeological evidence all support the African origin of modern humans.

questions.question_text: A heterozygous organism has two different alleles for a particular trait.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. A heterozygous organism has two different alleles for a gene — one from each parent. For example, Tt is heterozygous for the height gene (one dominant T allele and one recessive t allele). In contrast, homozygous means having two identical alleles (TT or tt).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Heterozygous (hetero = different) means the organism carries two different alleles for a trait. For example, Tt for height, where T = tall and t = short.

questions.question_text: In Mendel's monohybrid cross, the F2 genotypic ratio is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: In a monohybrid cross (Tt x Tt), the F2 genotypic ratio is 1:2:1 — meaning 1 TT (homozygous dominant) : 2 Tt (heterozygous) : 1 tt (homozygous recessive). This corresponds to the phenotypic ratio of 3:1 because TT and Tt both show the dominant trait.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is '1:2:1'. From the Punnett square of Tt x Tt: one-fourth TT, one-half Tt, one-fourth tt. The genotypic ratio (1:2:1) differs from the phenotypic ratio (3:1) because both TT and Tt show the dominant phenotype.

questions.question_text: The theory of evolution by natural selection was proposed by Charles ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Charles Darwin (1809-1882) proposed the theory of evolution by natural selection in his book 'On the Origin of Species' (1859). He observed that organisms with traits better suited to their environment survive and reproduce more, passing these advantageous traits to their offspring — a process he called 'natural selection' or 'survival of the fittest'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Darwin'. Charles Darwin, based on his observations during the voyage of HMS Beagle (especially on the Galapagos Islands), developed the theory that species evolve through natural selection acting on heritable variations.

questions.question_text: Organs that have no apparent function in the present organism but were functional in its ancestors are called ___ organs.
questions.explanation_correct: Vestigial organs are structures that have lost their original function through evolution but are still present in reduced or rudimentary form. In humans, examples include the appendix, wisdom teeth, and the coccyx (tailbone). They provide evidence of evolution by showing that ancestors had a different body plan.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vestigial'. These organs are remnants from ancestors where they were functional. Their presence in modern organisms indicates evolutionary ancestry and that organisms have changed over time.
